title: North East warn MPs warn Theresa May on damage to Nissan and car industry
text:

Dozens of North East MPs have warned Prime Minister Theresa May that her stance on hard Brexit will have a “damaging” impact on the region. 
The 24 Labour MPs have written to Mrs May with a series of questions about the region’s car making industry after the Prime Minister’s speech last week signalled the UK would not leave both the single market and the customs union when the country pulls out of the European Union. 
The letter follows comments from Nissan chief executive Carlos Ghosn at the end of last week that the company would have to “re-evaluate” the efficiency of its Sunderland plant after Brexit. Carlos Ghosn, Nissan Motor Corporation Chairman and CEO (Photo: Getty Images North America) 
Mr Ghosn said Nissan trusted previous Government assurances on the future competitiveness of the automotive industry, but his comments have re-ignited concerns over the future of the company’s plant on Wearside. 
Nissan employs 6,700 people at Sunderland with thousands more in the supply chain, and yesterday’s announcement of a £50m grant to the nearby International Advanced Manufacturing Park highlighted the importance of the industry to the North East. 
The letter, organised by the pro-single market Open Britain campaign, says that “Nissan’s investment in Sunderland was secured last year on a promise to maintain the status quo and is now jeopardised by your embrace of a hard Brexit.” 
Sunderland MP Julie Elliott, a supporter of the Open Britain campaign, said: “Theresa May has decided to follow a hard Brexit and as a result long-term investment in the North East is at risk. Julie Elliott 
“The Government’s greatest priority in the Brexit negotiations should be protecting jobs, like the many thousands employed by Nissan and its supply chain in the North East. 
“Outside the single market and customs union, jobs will be insecure as there will be new trade barriers between us and our largest trading partner – the EU . There is no mandate for this from voters. It is the Prime Minister’s choice and working people will pay the price. Read More Nissans to come in 'unlimited' thanks to Sunderland man's idea 
“If a hard Brexit does lead to people being laid off in Sunderland and elsewhere, the Prime Minister must swallow her pride, change course, and keep Britain in the single market and customs union.” 
The letter to the Prime Minister is signed by almost all of the Labour MPs from Tyne and Wear, Northumberland, County Durham and Teesside. Prime Minister Theresa May 
It says that the Goverment’s stance on Brexit ignores submissions from industry and business groups and is “siding instead with the political fantasies of a section of your party.” Read More Nissan will review its Sunderland plant after Brexit, boss says 
In the letter, Mrs May is asked to guarantee that jobs will not be lost in UK manufacturing as a result of the decision to leave the single market. 
The MPs add: “We of course accept the result of the referendum, we just reject your interpretation of what it means and want to protect jobs and industry.” 
The letter is signed by Dave Anderson, Roberta Blackman-Woods, Tom Blenkinsop, Alan Campbell, Ronnie Campbell, Jenny Chapman, Alex Cunningham, Julie Elliott, Pat Glass, Mary Glindon, Helen Goodman, Stephen Hepburn, Sharon Hodgson, Kevan Jones, Ian Lavery, Emma Lewell-Buck, Catherine McKinnell, Ian Mearns, Grahame Morris, Chi Onwurah, Bridget Phillipson, Anna Turley, Phil Wilson and Iain Wright. 
Downing Street has been approached for comment. Like us on Facebook
